Quick Start¶

This page will show some examples to load a sourced dataset or to make quicklook plots. For more details, please see User’s guide.

More examples can be found here.

Dock a Dataset¶

The example below shows how to dock a sourced dataset (Madrigal/EISCAT data) to the datahub.

examples/dock_a_dataset.py¶
 1import datetime
 2
 3from geospacelab.datahub import DataHub
 4
 5# settings
 6dt_fr = datetime.datetime.strptime('20210309' + '0000', '%Y%m%d%H%M')   # datetime from
 7dt_to = datetime.datetime.strptime('20210309' + '2359', '%Y%m%d%H%M')   # datetime to
 8database_name = 'madrigal'      # built-in sourced database name
 9facility_name = 'eiscat'        # facility name
10
11site = 'UHF'                # facility attributes required, check from the eiscat schedule page
12antenna = 'UHF'
13modulation = 'ant'
14
15# create a datahub instance
16dh = DataHub(dt_fr, dt_to)
17# dock a dataset
18ds_1 = dh.dock(datasource_contents=[database_name, facility_name],
19                      site=site, antenna=antenna, modulation=modulation, data_file_type='eiscat-hdf5')
20# load data
21ds_1.load_data()
22# assign a variable from its own dataset to the datahub
23n_e = dh.assign_variable('n_e')
24T_i = dh.assign_variable('T_i')
25
26# get the variables which have been assigned in the datahub
27n_e = dh.get_variable('n_e')
28T_i = dh.get_variable('T_i')
29# if the variable is not assigned in the datahub, but exists in the its own dataset:
30comp_O_p = dh.get_variable('comp_O_p', dataset=ds_1)     # O+ ratio
31# above line is equivalent to
32comp_O_p = dh.datasets[1]['comp_O_p']
33
34# The variables, e.g., n_e and T_i, are the class Variable's instances,
35# which stores the variable values, errors, and many other attributes, e.g., name, label, unit, depends, ....
36# To get the value of the variable, use variable_isntance.value, e.g.,
37print(n_e.value)        # return the variable's value, type: numpy.ndarray, axis 0 is always along the time, check n_e.depends.items{}
38print(n_e.error)

Quicklook Plots¶

The quicklook plots are produced by the method “quicklook” of a viewer, which is custom-designed for a data source. Those specialized viewer can be imported from geospacelab.express. The two examples below show the solar wind and geomagnetic indices, as well as the EISCAT data, respectively.

Solar Wind and Geomagnetic Indices from OMNI and WDC¶

examples/quicklook_omni_wdc.py¶
1

Output:

EISCAT from Madrigal with Marking Tools¶

examples/quicklook_eiscat.py¶
1

Output:
